header_summary:
The integration of a new signature algorithm, P256, into the Bitcoin protocol raises concerns about its feasibility and timing, given the multi-year process required for community consensus and high-quality implementation. This discussion, led by conduition, highlights the juxtaposition of ongoing developments in quantum-resistant cryptographic solutions against the backdrop of potential obsolescence due to the advent of quantum computing, suggesting a shift in focus towards post-quantum security might be more beneficial ([source](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/GVA2lG8TET5qUPOU8JlHttBNLbTskqr_dbhzK9aOe_ZsPsNDyk2kWIPwmx3ngTchlGrsAIpubrVl24qmyqVgBvrZ8FT0POeomam2qB6-cqk=@proton.me/T/#mb4648d11e6487def3a9204054abf8fe08f23543a)).

Tim Ruffing's examination of Bitcoin's Taproot in the context of post-quantum security reveals that an attacker with quantum computing capabilities would not compromise the system's integrity, based on the quantum random oracle model. This research supports a two-phase softfork upgrade path for integrating post-quantum signatures into Bitcoin, emphasizing the current adequacy of security measures against quantum threats while cautioning against complacency in the face of advancements in classical computing ([source](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/bee6b897379b9ae0c3d48f53d40a6d70fe7915f0.camel@real-or-random.org/T/#u#m92bcdcb0b0b26ea0138d2e09b8c1d2bbbc3eccb3)).

In parallel, the release of libsecp256k1 version 0.7.0 signifies a substantial update focused on enhancing the library’s stability and efficiency, evidencing the Bitcoin development community's commitment to continuous improvement. Furthermore, the unveiling of a new dataset and benchmarking tool for Bitcoin block fee spans and fee estimations by zpv, alongside a critical examination of network security challenges within the Lightning Network by Crypt-iQ, underscores the ongoing efforts to bolster Bitcoin's infrastructure and security ([source for libsecp256k1 update](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/659ec12e5b034d5c20ef15d88325e740a29c8182.camel@real-or-random.org/T/#u#m6b98ac4d6705500614b97ab9f4dc07b86ceaba34), [source for dataset release](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/augur-block-s-open-source-bitcoin-fee-estimation-library/1848/5)).

Lastly, sanket1729's exploration into post-quantum cryptography technologies highlights the efficiency and practicality of schemes like Musig/Frost over traditional ECDSA, reflecting the broader intent within the community to future-proof cryptographic practices against quantum computing threats ([source](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/post-quantum-hd-wallets-silent-payments-key-aggregation-and-threshold-signatures/1854/2)).

recent_posts.title: Revisiting secp256r1 signatures (i.e. P256, mobile HSM support)
recent_posts.summary:
- Integrating P256 into Bitcoin is a multi-year process, involving community consensus and soft fork execution.
- The introduction of quantum computing and discussions on post-quantum cryptography may outpace P256 integration.
- Concerns arise about WebAuthn's compatibility with Bitcoin, particularly for user autonomy and post-quantum security.

recent_posts.title: Taproot is post-quantum secure when restricted to script-path spends
recent_posts.summary:
- A study shows Bitcoin's Taproot is post-quantum secure under script-path spending assumptions.
- It recommends a two-phase softfork for Bitcoin to incorporate post-quantum signatures safely.
- Despite quantum threats, the focus should remain on classical computing risks to Taproot's security.

recent_posts.title: libsecp256k1 v0.7.0 released
recent_posts.summary:
- Libsecp256k1 version 0.7.0 focuses on maintenance improvements, enhancing API and ABI compatibility.
- It introduces more stable, efficient library features and deprecates old private key function aliases.
- Version 0.7.0 now fully supports CMake, facilitating easier integration for developers.

recent_posts.title: Augur: Block’s Open Source Bitcoin Fee Estimation Library
recent_posts.summary:
- A new dataset and benchmarking tool for Bitcoin fee analysis was released.
- It covers data from January to June 2025, aiming to aid cryptocurrency stakeholders.
- Users are encouraged to explore and give feedback, with resources available on GitHub.

recent_posts.title: Disclosure: LND gossip_timestamp_filter DoS
recent_posts.summary:
- The email addresses a failed attempt to stop a stealth attack on the Lightning Network.
- The mitigation strategy was ineffective, allowing bypass via multiple node IDs.
- The author personally acknowledges the flaw in strategy, highlighting openness in development.

recent_posts.title: Post-Quantum HD-Wallets, Silent Payments, Key Aggregation, and Threshold Signatures
recent_posts.summary:
- Post-quantum cryptography's potential exceeds current standards like ECDSA in efficiency and security.
- Focus is on comparing PQ schemes with ECDSA, aiming to find more practical, performance-enhanced options.
- The goal is to identify quantum-resistant cryptographic technologies suitable for real-world application and future cybersecurity.

active_posts.title: A Post Quantum Migration Proposal
active_posts.summary:
- Jameson Lopp's blog post proposes enhancing Bitcoin's defense against quantum threats.
- The proposal includes a transition to post-quantum cryptography with a phased approach.
- It emphasizes the urgent need for migration to secure Bitcoin's network and economic value.

active_posts.title: Human meaningful witness versioning
active_posts.summary:
- Ava Chow proposes a mnemonic criterion for Bitcoin Witness Versions allocation.
- The proposal aims to enhance user safety and understanding of transaction types.
- This mnemonic system follows the "bc" and "tc" prefix usage for clarity and security.

active_posts.title: [BIP Proposal] Proof-of-Activity Reclamation (PoAR)
active_posts.summary:
- Donald Dienst proposed a new Bitcoin Improvement Proposal titled "Proof-of-Activity Reclamation (PoAR)."- The proposal aims to recycle inactive bitcoins over twenty years into circulation without exceeding the 21 million cap.
- Dienst encourages community feedback on the document available on GitHub for collaborative development.

active_posts.title: Changes to BIP-360 - Pay to Quantum Resistant Hash (P2QRH)
active_posts.summary:
- Recent BIP-360 updates aim to enhance Bitcoin’s defense against quantum threats.
- Key changes include shifting P2QRH to a taproot-based script, increasing quantum security.
- The proposal also separates PQ signature development, allowing flexible, future-proof upgrades.

active_posts.title: Exploring Extended Relative Timelocks
active_posts.summary:
- Exploration of extending Bitcoin timelocks to ~10 years is driven by user feedback.
- A method proposed involves modifying the `nSequence` field's bit 21 to signal long timelocks.
- The experiment includes developing tools for creating compliant addresses and transactions.

active_posts.title: Where does the 33.33% threshold for selfish mining come from?
active_posts.summary:
- The 2013 paper analyzes selfish mining, where miners gain more than their fair share.
- Selfish mining is profitable over one-third of the network hashrate, with block propagation speed as a factor.
- Findings show selfish mining's profitability threshold lies between 36% and 37% of the network hashrate.

today_in_history_posts.title: BIP Proposals for Output Script Descriptors
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Andrew Chow proposes formalizing Output Script Descriptors in 7 BIPs for wallet issues.
- The proposal includes various descriptors and suggests dropping the combo() descriptor.
- These descriptors, implemented since Bitcoin Core 0.17, enhance output script specification.

today_in_history_posts.title: Removing the Dust Limit
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Jeremy Rubin proposes removing Bitcoin's dust limit, offering five supportive reasons.
- He challenges the dust limit by highlighting its restriction on smart contracts and privacy concerns.
- Rubin counters concerns over spam and fingerprinting attacks, advocating for preventive measures by wallets.

today_in_history_posts.title: Bolt 12 Trusted Contacts
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Bolt 12 aims to simplify lightning wallet transactions by enabling user-managed contact lists and metadata-based offers.
- It proposes a privacy-respecting way for selective identity revelation through `contact_key` sharing and mutual authentication methods.
- The post concludes by seeking developer feedback on these proposed methods to refine and standardize the user experience in Bolt 12 payments.
